content.description: Dope Heel Hook off the sit-start, leads to a huge slap. Bust out some sick foot work and make your way up the right side of the arete. Get ready to use some crimp and pinch strength on this one.
content.location: Just up and behind the "FLYSWATTER" by like 20ft, left of the Jewel when facing the mountain (not in the same nook as Jewel. It has a nice "terraced" landing. Protect yourself from the boulder on the right, as you top out.

content.description: This is a beautiful line hidden from the trail on a gently overhanging face. Begin at an inset right-hand edge and a microcrimp and head straight up, starting with a big move. Mind the landing.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spot, the landing is a rising slab over a pit with ankle-breaker potential.
content.location: Look uphill in the vicinity of the Bill Boulder for a large slabby boulder, this problem is on its overhanging back side.

climbs.name: Flyswatter
climbs.fa: either Bob Murray or John Sherman

content.description: Well-known as a historic Flagstaff testpiece and as a benchmark for V8. Tip-rending crimps, slick knobs and small footholds lead from the lip of the overhang out the pretty bulge. Cold weather, fresh skin and intuitive footwork will come in handy.
content.location: East side of the boulder, right of the graffiti, climb roughly straight up from a stand start on the thin crimps around head height.

content.description: Climb the bulging arete on palm-grating slopers, starting at a sloping pocket and a small knob. Turn the lip with a difficult mantel on poor holds.
content.location: Right of the BILL graffiti, to the left of Flyswatter.

content.description: The Bill Boulder (graffiti: "BILL P WAS HERE") is home to the crimping testpiece Flyswatter, an original benchmark for the V8 grade. Many problems exist on the caves and boulders above BILL.
